TL;DR:
I know you won't read this whole thing. This game is amazing, and revolutionizes the Souls formula, providing an incredible experience and proving that not just Fromsoft can make a Souls game.

Lies of P is a revolutionary game. It, I believe, has finally made a necessary jump that inumerable gamers have desired for years, whether they knew it or not. What I believe Lies of P has done is finally break the monopoly Fromsoft has on the Souls-like genre. 

While there are almost inevitably countless smaller games that have taken ideas from the Soulsbourne games or made games of the genre, and ripples of Souls concepts have become included in almost every AAA release, no other major studio has attempted to create a game that could be considered a true Souls-like down to its core. The creators of Lies of P have finally tackled the intimidating prospect of creating a game to rival Fromsoft's masterpieces, and they did an incredible job. 

The gameplay, while a bit stiff at times, is lovely. Taking a page out of Sekiro's handbook, guarding perfectly is your main way of dealing with larger enemies, while dodging is a vital second option for when you need to create space or can't block the attack. Unlike Sekiro, however, the game is not completely based on parrying, with no deathblow system, and has a customization and build variety on par with Bloodbourne or even Elden Ring. There are at least 3 dozen unique weapons in this game, and almost every one is viable and interesting.

Two twists on the formula elevate the system to be on par or perhaps even better than Elden Ring's weapons systems. Much like Elden Ring, each weapon has special abilities that can be swapped out. The way that works in this game, though, is that you can swap the actual head of the weapon to be on the handle of a different weapon, mixing and matching different components to create unique weapons with different basic movesets, charge attacks, and even ranges, on top of the different "fable" abilities of the blade and handle.

The next level of customization is incredibly cool, and makes me wonder why no one thought of it sooner, which is that you can directly affect the scaling of weapons in the game using cranks. You can make any weapon work with any build this way and get full (or at least better) scaling out of it. I have never seen a game with this much build variety, short of Elden Ring, which is a crazy comparison considering that game is absolutely massive, and build variety that is very interesting.

While there is even more build variety to this game in the Legion Arms and P-Organ, I literally don't have enough space to write about them so let's cover area exploration instead. This game's levels feel a lot like Dark Souls 3, which has some of my favorite levels in between the bosses. They're generally pretty simple in concept, though greatly enjoyable in execution. While nothing particularly special, they're certainly on par with the Souls Series, though there is a severe lack of poison swamps in this game. While not flashy or exciting, they are nonetheless a wonderful time.

At the end of every zone is a bossfight, and they are absolutely excellent. There very are few boss fights in this game I'd consider frustrating, and the ones that are good are absolute gold. The nearly flawless implementation of Sekiro ideas in a more traditional Souls body, mixed with boss design that's in between Dark Souls 3 and Elden Ring, create a soup of excellent video game perfection. While the game is a little held back by the timings of perfect guarding, which always felt a little off, this awkwardness quickly fades away as you learn the boss and get to know it's moveset and weaknesses. The frustration of hitting the proverbial wall melts into bliss as you perfectly counter and weave between the bosses attacks, having learned their moves and patterns. The fight against the King Puppet, mostly it's second phase, is perhaps one of my favorite fights in any souls game. And, like the Souls Games, a good build will scoot you on by the rougher fights, unlike the purely-skill based Sekiro, which wasn't for everyone.

Now, perhaps one of the most important parts of Lies of P that truly defines it as something not made by Fromsoft, but instead inspired by. That would be this game's story. We Fromsoft gamers have grown very used to the cryptic and grimdark world building of the Soulsbourne games. You explore a decaying land with a decent idea of your goal and, with careful study of the environment, items, and characters, you can piece together a number of correlated tragic tales often stretching centuries or even millennia into the past. A weakness of this system is that most people won't be able to really get what's going on or the tragedy of the games until looking online, though.

To say it is a breath of fresh air to play a souls game that is neither extremely cryptic nor nearly as grim would be an understatement. This game has an excellent cast of wonderfully voiced characters that have engaging stories and personalities, and most of whom don't die hopeless and sad! Perhaps the highest praise that I can give this game is that it made me cry. I doubt there is a single person on the planet, short of season 8 Spongebob Squarepants, who would cry playing any Souls game. They're too bleak, too grim, and too confusing to be emotionally invested in. It's hard to feel anything when Dark Souls NPC #22 dies at the end of their questline, either because you're rereading the wiki to make sure you actually did the damn thing right, or because every other character also has something horrible happen to them in every other quest or story. Lies of P lights a torch from Fromsoft's brazier and carries it to new places, themes, ideas, and emotions. The music in this game is perhaps some of my favorite video game music, and I don't just mean the regular tracks, though those are certainly fine, but the records. The record I got after a certain character died... that made me cry as the song took me on a journey of remembering my journey, the characters I had met, and the final steps I had yet to take. I have never felt anything like it in almost any game before, let alone a Souls Game!

Overall, Lies of P is the best Souls-like not made by Fromsoft. Actually, Scratch that. That doesn't do this game justice. Simply treating this game as something in the shadow of the giant doesn't truly get across the genius of this game. I believe that this game deserves to stand alongside its genre's namesake. Souls-like doesn't make sense as a name anymore, now that the floodgates have opened and companies other than Fromsoft can make this genre of masterpiece. This is a game that takes from the clay Fromsoft has used for years, and sculpts something new. I would then, in honor of Lies of P and the legacy of the Souls games, propose that we rename the genre of Souls-like to a SoulRPG. These games are no longer merely "like" an old game, that they exist only in the shadow, or to continue, an older game. They have, in my opinion, graduated to another branch in the tree of RPG subgenres, flowering with unique buds created by many kinds of pollen. (I don't actually think Souls-like is a bad or insufficient name, I'm just trying to be dramatic). Buy this game now, I look forward to the DLC!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

I had heard good things about Lies of P, as someone who has played all of the core FromSoftware games; and still I was hesitant to give it a try, out of worry this would be another clunky attempt to clone the mechanics and concepts from their games. I am glad to say this game surpassed all of my expectations and was in fact one of the most polished, creative, and enjoyable Soulslike games I have ever played; reaching and even surpassing, in some places, a good chunk of FromSoftware's own experiences. If you are still wary of giving this game a try don't be. I am writing this review at the end of my first play-through with intentions to go and get all achievements. The environments are beautiful and engaging. The music is distinct and true to form. And, the quests/NPC stories, throughout, gave me a commensurate drive to keep going in between every play session. I think my only critique is that the game never felt as challenging as any of the original Soulsborne games, often vying for a richer story and smoother experience. This for me detracts a tiny bit from the experience of the game. since part of why I enjoy the Soulsborne games is that they are quite a challenge at parts. Overall though, this is not a FromSoftware title and Neowiz has their own game-making philosophy; and, regardless, the overall creativity and depth of the "dark bloody children's book" theme continues to drive my interest despite the lack of challenge. The idea of multiple titles themed around stories like the Wizard of Oz or Alice in Wonderland, makes me open my wallet like a deranged mimic of Pavlov's Dog. If Neowiz continues with what they have made here, I have no doubt they will have an incredible series of games unlike what we have ever seen.

Lies of P is a convoluted hodge-podge of a bunch of different ideas, art directions, and game mechanics, mashed together into a game that is entirely too difficult for casual gamers and too linear and combat focused to give the lore room to breathe.

That said, I played the whole damn thing and had a good time, though I did use several mods in order to decrease the difficulty further with better parry windows and no stamina depletion.

Lies of P is first and foremost a combat game. You fight bad guys, and boss bad guys, and you dodge and block, and then hit them when they're down. Rinse and repeat. The gameplay loop doesn't get too tiring (at least from my modded perspective, as I wasn't dying nearly as much as vanilla), the enemies have a solid amount of variety, and the various settings and locations are beautiful and haunting to look at.

One thing this game excels at is switching things up as soon as you get comfortable. They start you out with simple melee opponents, but over time you have to deal with spitting acid, bombs, bullets, and even giant cannons firing down on you. Even enemies that are clearly remixes of previous enemies have slightly new movesets or tricks up their sleeves to prevent you from fully anticipating their attacks.

The lie mechanic is a fascinating concept that feels largely underutilized, especially in the first half of the game. You spend most of your time killing enemies and very little time roleplaying/having moral dilemmas where you must lie/be honest. There are a few sidequests where you will be given more opportunities to practice your lying/truthing, but those sections are often completely out of the way and can easily be missed without a walkthrough of some sort. Failure to encounter those areas will prevent you from achieving the "human" ending as you will not have committed enough lying (this game doesn't do "save states," so you will have to start over from square one in order to achieve a different ending).

The lore is also sidelined a lot, and reduced to scattered notes that you must pause the game to read through. Many of these notes, like the lie mechanic, are located in areas that you can easily miss going from place to place, which kinda sucks considering some of the lore is very fascinating when you get the chance to read about it. I'm not saying Lies of P should've added a ton of unskippable cutscenes or long, drawn-out lore dumps, but I am saying that the game sort of... expects you to know a lot of the lore out of the box? In some ways, it almost feels like I am playing a tie-in game for a larger universe, one that I am expected to have read-up on beforehand.

Back to the combat a bit- this game draws heavily from the soulslike genre in how it plays. If you are not a soulslike gamer, DO NOT PLAY THIS GAME, unless you are willing to mod it like I did in order to tone down the experience. Even on the easiest difficulty setting, some of the bosses will genuinely stun-lock you or jam you into a corner and beat you to death over and over until you're sick of it. The stamina pool is very small, and the ways to increase stamina and improve your stats are not very intuitive for someone casual like myself to figure out.

You can read reviews and studies about this game or watch videos on YouTube, which will tell you that even for a soulslike game, the parry windows, hitboxes, and boss difficulties are all insanely high and a bit broken/janky from a technical perspective, which is largely why I didn't lose any sleep over modding the damn thing in order to enjoy it (I had already purchased it, after all, and didn't want to just have it sit there on steam).

All of this to say, my overall experience was a mixed bag. I say play it once, as there is a lot of good material in there, but I wouldn't necessarily recommend paying full price for it, and I definitely wouldn't recommend trying to do New Game Plus or anything like that. One playthrough is plenty for me, at least.

Soulslikes really are video game royalty: capriciously cruel, inexplicably beloved, and so massively inbred they all share the DNA of a handful of decrepit progenitors. How this genre continues to thrive with practically everyone slavishly copying FromSoftware is beyond me. Very rarely is there an infusion of new blood, and then we're treated to a masterpiece like Hollow Knight or the better of the two Nioh games. Lies of P is what happens the rest of the time. 

It's strangely appropriate that a game loosely based on The Adventures of Pinocchio imitates Bloodborne with all the inarticulate clumsiness of a wooden puppet. Tone, atmosphere, and even entire story beats are lifted wholesale. Stop me if you've heard this one before. The city of [strike]Yharnam[/strike] Krat, elevated to widespread renown through the miraculous properties of a mysterious substance known as [strike]The Old Blood[/strike] Ergo, is suffering from an outbreak of an unknown disease, possibly connected to a sinister, cult-like organization called [strike]The Healing Church[/strike] The Alchemists. You are a [strike]Hunter[/strike] Stalker, newly awakened in [strike]Yharnam[/strike] Krat, navigating a city on the brink of ruin, all the while trying to figure out exactly what is going on and how to stop it. 

Combat mechanics focus on blocking, rather than dodging (which is a lot weaker than in the Soulsborne games), as Lies of P fuses Bloodborne's rally with Sekiro's deflection, distorting both in the most annoying way possible. An imperfectly-timed block leads to stamina drain and chip damage that can be healed by landing attacks, while a perfectly-timed one will prevent all damage and simultaneously reduce the posture of your opponent. Do enough posture damage, and you can open them up to a finishing move.

It should already be clear this kind of system encourages defensive play, with perfect guarding and countering taking the place of Sekiro's continuous aggression or Bloodborne's fighting through incoming attacks. Thus, the game becomes slower, more tedious, and more static, with no tangible benefits in exchange. Even worse, bosses frequently have uninterruptible multi-hit combos, forcing you to block or parry until you can finally ‚Äútake your turn‚Äù. Patiently waiting while a lady dressed in a metal gimp suit does her best combine harvester impression a few inches from my face is not my idea of fun. 

The reduction of the parry window (Sekiro's 12 frames to Lies of P's 8) makes fighting inconsistent and unrewarding. Several times I went from barely doing any damage to a boss during one attempt to instantly defeating it the next, because I was suddenly perfectly guarding all of its attacks. There was no learning process or gradual accumulation of mastery, which felt wholly unsatisfying, like winning had nothing to do with anything I did. 

Not that there's much satisfaction to be found anywhere in the game. The bosses are an unhealthy combination of too easy and too frustrating. I repeatedly noticed a fight that was over in 30-40 minutes felt like it had taken hours. Time sure drags on when you're not having any fun. However, even at its most punishing (probably sometime around the two-thirds mark in the main game or at the very end of the DLC), Lies of P never quite matches the sheer sadism of the Souls series, let alone Elden Ring. This actually makes the game less engaging, since it's just not hard enough to create immersion through difficulty. 

Outside of boss and miniboss encounters, the levels are so forgettably bland, I'm already having trouble remembering anything about them. Was there a factory and maybe a train station? What is the point of all the fancy textures when every area is designed like the digestive tract of a nematode? Half the appeal of Soulslikes is exploration. You can jump over a suspiciously low balcony railing or step into an innocuous-looking painting and end up in a completely new world. Here everything is so linear it might as well be on-rails.

What is this game even about? Parts of it don't make any sense. There is a core mechanic that ties your character's humanity to his ability to tell lies. The more human and less puppet-like you become by the end of the game, the better the final ending. Now, it would seem to me that having to constantly lie to get the best ending makes you just as lacking in self-determination as a puppet that is programmed to only tell the truth, but what would I know? Concepts like ‚Äúludonarrative dissonance‚Äù are ultimately meaningless when neither the ‚Äúludum‚Äù nor the ‚Äúnarrative‚Äù is interesting enough to be worth analyzing.

Soulslikes really are video game royalty: capriciously cruel, inexplicably beloved, and so massively inbred they all share the DNA of a handful of decrepit progenitors. How this genre continues to thrive with practically everyone slavishly copying FromSoftware is beyond me. Very rarely is there an infusion of new blood, and then we're treated to a masterpiece like Hollow Knight or the better of the two Nioh games. Lies of P is what happens the rest of the time. 

It's strangely appropriate that a game loosely based on The Adventures of Pinocchio imitates Bloodborne with all the inarticulate clumsiness of a wooden puppet. Tone, atmosphere, and even entire story beats are lifted wholesale. Stop me if you've heard this one before. The city of [strike]Yharnam[/strike] Krat, elevated to widespread renown through the miraculous properties of a mysterious substance known as [strike]The Old Blood[/strike] Ergo, is suffering from an outbreak of an unknown disease, possibly connected to a sinister, cult-like organization called [strike]The Healing Church[/strike] The Alchemists. You are a [strike]Hunter[/strike] Stalker, newly awakened in [strike]Yharnam[/strike] Krat, navigating a city on the brink of ruin, all the while trying to figure out exactly what is going on and how to stop it. 

Combat mechanics focus on blocking, rather than dodging (which is a lot weaker than in the Soulsborne games), as Lies of P fuses Bloodborne's rally with Sekiro's deflection, distorting both in the most annoying way possible. An imperfectly-timed block leads to stamina drain and chip damage that can be healed by landing attacks, while a perfectly-timed one will prevent all damage and simultaneously reduce the posture of your opponent. Do enough posture damage, and you can open them up to a finishing move.

It should already be clear this kind of system encourages defensive play, with perfect guarding and countering taking the place of Sekiro's continuous aggression or Bloodborne's fighting through incoming attacks. Thus, the game becomes slower, more tedious, and more static, with no tangible benefits in exchange. Even worse, bosses frequently have uninterruptible multi-hit combos, forcing you to block or parry until you can finally ‚Äútake your turn‚Äù. Patiently waiting while a lady dressed in a metal gimp suit does her best combine harvester impression a few inches from my face is not my idea of fun. 

The reduction of the parry window (Sekiro's 12 frames to Lies of P's 8) makes fighting inconsistent and unrewarding. Several times I went from barely doing any damage to a boss during one attempt to instantly defeating it the next, because I was suddenly perfectly guarding all of its attacks. There was no learning process or gradual accumulation of mastery, which felt wholly unsatisfying, like winning had nothing to do with anything I did. 

Not that there's much satisfaction to be found anywhere in the game. The bosses are an unhealthy combination of too easy and too frustrating. I repeatedly noticed a fight that was over in 30-40 minutes felt like it had taken hours. Time sure drags on when you're not having any fun. However, even at its most punishing (probably sometime around the two-thirds mark in the main game or at the very end of the DLC), Lies of P never quite matches the sheer sadism of the Souls series, let alone Elden Ring. This actually makes the game less engaging, since it's just not hard enough to create immersion through difficulty. 

Outside of boss and miniboss encounters, the levels are so forgettably bland, I'm already having trouble remembering anything about them. Was there a factory and maybe a train station? What is the point of all the fancy textures when every area is designed like the digestive tract of a nematode? Half the appeal of Soulslikes is exploration. You can jump over a suspiciously low balcony railing or step into an innocuous-looking painting and end up in a completely new world. Here everything is so linear it might as well be on-rails.

What is this game even about? Parts of it don't make any sense. There is a core mechanic that ties your character's humanity to his ability to tell lies. The more human and less puppet-like you become by the end of the game, the better the final ending. Now, it would seem to me that having to constantly lie to get the best ending makes you just as lacking in self-determination as a puppet that is programmed to only tell the truth, but what would I know? Concepts like ‚Äúludonarrative dissonance‚Äù are ultimately meaningless when neither the ‚Äúludum‚Äù nor the ‚Äúnarrative‚Äù is interesting enough to be worth analyzing.
